MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Insurance (Intermittent Unemployment) Act, 1942.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare whether he intends to introduce proposals to amend the Insurance (Intermittent Unemployment) Act, 1942, so as to bring quarry workers, especially the employees at Muckish Mountain, County Donegal, within its provisions.

I would refer the Deputy to my reply to a question put to me by Deputy Seán Dunne on the 15th June, 1948, in which I indicated that there had been no general demand for the inclusion of quarry workers in the wet-time scheme. I also stated on that occasion that I would be glad to consider any representations which might be made for the extension of the scheme to additional classes of workers. I have not since received any indication that quarry workers desire to be brought within the scope of the wet-time scheme.

The mountain where this work is carried on is high above the Donegal coast and the workers there are exposed to all kinds of weathers. There is only a sort of shelter. This industry is a very important one of procuring sand for glass-making. Would it not be in the interests of the industry to bring these people within the scope of the Act? As the Minister is already aware, some county councils are making provision for broken time for the workers.

The Deputy will appreciate that if quarry workers are brought into the scheme they must be brought in as quarry workers nationally employed over the whole territory of this State. I cannot merely take in those in an exposed part of Donegal and exclude those from other portions of the country. As I said to Deputy Dunne some time ago, I am willing to discuss with any representative body of workers or employers the extension of the wet-time scheme to any classes of workers, bearing in mind all the time that such funds as have accumulated— what might be described as the “wet-time treasury”—have been put there by the contributions of other classes of workers and their employers. That must be borne in mind in considering any extension of the scheme to other classes of workers. However, the net position is that I am willing to discuss the matter with anybody who claims to be able to speak authoritatively for quarry workers.

Seeing that this particular industry is not quarry work like county council work but a quarry producing sand for a glass-making industry, and in the interests of keeping the industry in full swing and probably stopping the importation of glasses from abroad, could not the Minister look into this particular industry in Donegal apart from including any other workers?

I have no such power. I doubt very much whether I have any power under the Act as it now stands to extend the scope of the Act to any workers other than building trade workers or what might be described as ancillary workers. I doubt if I have any power to extend it to quarry workers as such without new legislation. If I had such power, however, it would be to extend it to quarry workers as a whole and not to workers employed in a particular part of the country.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Conditions in Dundrum Asylum.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has now ascertained whether the room in which two attendants in Dundrum Criminal Lunatic Asylum were sleeping when they successively contracted tuberculosis was disinfected after the condition of the first attendant had been diagnosed and he had been removed to hospital and before the second attendant contracted the disease; and if he will state (a) the manner; (b) by whom; and (c) the date on which the mattress of the first attendant's bed was destroyed and when it was replaced.

I have made further inquiries in regard to this case and I have ascertained that the floor of the room occupied by the two attendants referred to by the Deputy was washed with disinfectant on several occasions during the short period in which the first attendant, whom I shall continue to call attendant B, was confined to bed therein. The floor was similarly washed after attendant B had been removed to hospital.

On the basis of information supplied by the Dundrum Asylum authorities, I stated in reply to the Deputy's previous question of 16th December, 1948, on this subject that the mattress on the bed of attendant B was destroyed immediately after the attendant had been taken to hospital. I am now informed that, while the mattress was taken away on the day following that on which the attendant was brought to hospital, the mattress itself was not actually destroyed or burnt, but that it was cast away in a separate storeroom, together with other stores, condemned as unfit for further use. The mattress was replaced three months later in April, 1947. As I have already informed the Deputy, I am satisfied that the precautionary measures generally taken by the Dundrum Asylum authorities were adequate to prevent the likelihood of the spread of the disease.

Arising out of the Minister's reply, while I have no personal knowledge of the circumstances of this case, would it surprise the Minister to learn that there are people who are prepared to give evidence on oath, if necessary, that the mattress in question used by attendant B in this particular case was neither destroyed nor given away, but is still in use under an inmate at the present time or, at least, was in use up to quite recently? Further, is it not obligatory when a person is removed to hospital suffering from an infectious disease—even from a private dwellinghouse—to have the room occupied by such person sealed and disinfected?

In reply to the Deputy, that is quite a serious charge he has made. I feel that in justice to the authorities in Dundrum Asylum I should give them an opportunity of answering that charge and I shall be very glad to have the whole matter further investigated. In that investigation I hope I shall receive the assistance of the Deputy in carrying it out. With regard to infectious diseases and the sterilisation of rooms, disinfecting is carried out in certain cases but the absolute necessity of doing this is not completely established. I repeat that the precautions which it has been reported to me were taken by the authorities were adequate to prevent a further spread of the infectious disease.

As I have already said, I have no personal knowledge of this particular case but I will co-operate with the Minister by all means if the people who gave me the information will make it available for the Minister.
Can the Minister tell us how long attendant B was ill and how long he was occupying the same room as the other attendant before his illness was diagnosed and he was removed?

In reply to a similar question by the Deputy on a previous occasion I informed the Deputy that the man became ill in January; his illness was diagnosed in January and he was removed on the 4th February.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Health Services Grants.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health whether it is a fact that the amount provided by the Dáil in respect of health services grants for the current year has been exhausted and that in consequence the local authorities have been notified that these grants will not be paid this year on the customary dates; and, if so, to state the reasons why the grants in question have been found to be insufficient and the statutory obligations of the Exchequer to the local authorities have not been honoured.

The amount provided by the Dáil in respect of health services grants for the current year has proved insufficient for the reason that the estimates of expenditure furnished by health authorities prior to the date upon which I took up office have been exceeded for various reasons, including (a) the provision of over 800 extra beds for persons suffering from tuberculosis, (b) the payment of increased bonus to health authority staffs and (c) the introduction of a 96-hour fortnight for nurses and mental hospital attendants, etc.

The Deputy is aware that the Estimate for my Department for the health services grant must necessarily be based upon the figures furnished by health authorities, and that any substantial increase in actual expenditure by health authorities in excess of these figures involves a Supplementary Estimate for the health services grant.
There is no date fixed by statute by which these grants must be paid.
Health authorities were informed on the 20th December that the second instalment of the grant will be paid in full before the end of the financial year.
84 per cent. of the estimated health services grant due for the current financial year has already been paid.

Arising out of the Minister's reply, does the Minister suggest that the provision of 800 beds spread all over the Twenty-Six Counties has been responsible for such an increase in the estimates of the local authorities as to render the money provided by the Dáil for the purpose of this health services grant insufficient?

I did not, of course, say that. That is one of the items which I mentioned as one of the causes giving rise to the necessity for the introduction of a Supplementary Estimate. I would point out to the Deputy that he will, if he wishes, have an opportunity of further discussing this matter on my Estimate.
Perhaps I may, but at the moment can the Minister say what the total expenditure was on the provision of these additional beds? To what extent is it responsible for the deficit in the Estimate?
It is, of course, quite impossible to give you exactly the proportion for which these beds are responsible.
What did the 800 beds cost?
Are you objecting to the provision of these 800 beds?

The Deputy is aware that it is not the actual provision of the beds that is responsible for the Supplementary Estimate. He must appreciate and understand that a lot of that expenditure would be taken as capital expenditure and consequently would not arise completely on my Supplementary Estimate. The beds would involve the employment of additional staff and in that way would increase the commitments of the local authorities.

Did the local authorities request that the 96-hour fortnight should be granted or that these additional sums to which he has referred should be provided for, or was it merely at the instance of the Minister himself?
Does the Deputy object to these provisions?
That is not the point. I am not asking you.
I know it is not the point.

I have made recommendations to the local authorities. As the Deputy is well aware, I cannot use force in regard to any recommendations—particularly in regard to the 96-hour fortnight or the provision of additional beds, but I have been fortunate in meeting a considerable amount of intelligent co-operation by the local authorities in my suggestions that these improvements should be brought about.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cattle Exports.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Dillon) James M. Dillon
Speaker.P: I am obliged to the Deputy for directing my attention to this characteristic falsification of the news in the Irish Press. The statement referred to appeared in a paragraph the heading of which is “Cattle Export Drop”. The paragraph then sets out that cattle shipments from Ireland in January, 1949, were 17,343, or 1,468 more than in January, 1948. This, of course, reveals a satisfactory increase in our shipments, so the enterprising journalist then sets out cattle shipments from Northern Ireland for January, 1949, at 5,685, representing a drop of 1,987 on the figure for January, 1948; he then blandly justifies his heading by the Northern Ireland figures, though the clear implication of the heading is that the decline in shipments referred to shipments from Ireland. Speaker.P: I should like to draw the Minister's attention to the great dissatisfaction that is felt against his officials and his Department due to the delays that local authorities are experiencing in getting a reply from his Department. On last Saturday four weeks, the Cork Joint Sanatorium Committee held a meeting to consider the provision of accommodation for nurses and maids adjacent to the new chest hospital. If that accommodation was provided the committee would be able to accommodate about 24 extra patients. The Minister was very anxious that we should go ahead with this. As I have said, on Saturday four weeks we sent up a communication to the Department and pointed out that we were holding a special meeting on that day fortnight to consider the Department's reply so that we could go ahead quickly with this project. The meeting was held on Saturday fortnight. Members of the committee attended from all over the County Cork, from Skibbereen, Clonakilty, Boherbee, Buttevant, Mitchelstown and the City of Cork. All these members attended the meeting at considerable expense to the ratepayers, but they discovered when they assembled that there was not even an acknowledgment of their communication of two weeks earlier from the Department. At a meeting of the joint sanatorium committee Deputy McAuliffe presided, and Deputy Seán Keane, Deputy Corry and myself were also present. The meeting unanimously adopted a resolution protesting against the delaying tactics of this Department.

This motion of protest that I am speaking about was proposed and seconded by supporters of the inter-Party Government. MainHeading.P: Deputies are concerned with my reply to Deputy MacEntee's question, in which I mentioned the 800 beds for tuberculous patients which have been provided since February last. The House is very anxious to know how much of the total Supplementary Estimate reflects this increase in beds. I am most anxious indeed to supply this information, but I would like it to be known that the information I am giving can be only very rough. If Deputies appreciate that the cost of providing one bed at present is approximately £1,200 to £1,400, it will be obvious that the provision of 800 beds would involve a very much greater capital sum than is mentioned in this Supplementary Estimate. The grants under sub-head H.— Grants to Health Authorities—include the allowances for dependents, which were amended during the year to include a wider range of patients and which, in my opinion, added to the benefits which these allowances confer on tuberculous patients and patients suffering from infectious diseases who come under these allowances. The success of this scheme, I think, is best seen in the fact that in the middle of last year—there were no figures available for February; they were not kept; I got them in July — approximately 1,050 persons were awaiting admission. Since this time last year we have provided approximately 850 beds. If we had a static waiting list, our problem would be a very tiny one indeed to-day; it would have left us a waiting list of approximately 150 patients. But, due largely to the fact that these allowances have enabled men and women to accept early diagnosis and treatment for their disease—a very good thing and a very desirable thing—our present waiting list has grown to approximately 991 patients, that is, 850 beds have been eaten up and we are now left with nearly 1,000 patients awaiting admission. I feel quite certain that with a continuance of the very considerable degree of co-operation which we have received throughout the country from all local authorities and from the members of all political Parties, we shall meet this problem in the reasonably near future and completely absorb the present waiting list.

Deputy Allen is anxious to protect the rights of local authorities and he gave expression to his conception of democratic government. As a matter of fact, I think I have carried out to a very much fuller degree than previously, this attempt to leave to local authorities as much responsibility as possible. In pursuance of that, in the last few months particularly, I think it right to say that practically every county manager and medical officer of health has been in my Department where we have had most fruitful and useful discussions concerning the whole health problem throughout the country. We in the Department have found these discussions very helpful indeed. We now feel that the local authorities are aware of our problems, and we are beginning to see more fully their difficulties. That is a policy in which I have the strongest and firmest belief. I hope for a continuance of that co-operation from the members of all local authorities, particularly in view of the fact that in the near future it is believed that representatives on local authorities will have restored to them some of these democratic rights which hitherto had been, may I say, rather curtailed.

MainHeading.Title: Committee on Finance. - Vote 59—Unemployment Insurance and Unemployment Assistance.

Speaker.P: I move:—

That a supplementary sum not exceeding £26,913 be granted to defray the Charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending 31st March, 1949, for Expenses in connection with Unemployment Insurance (including contributions to the Unemployment Fund and the cost of Supplements), Unemployment Assistance (including the cost of supplements and allowances), the Special Register of Agricultural and Turf Workers, and the provision of Labour for Harvest Work (9 Edw. 7, c. 7; 10 & 11 Geo. 5, c. 30; 11 Geo. 5, c. 1; 11 & 12 Geo. 5, c. 15; 12 Geo. 5, c. 7; No. 17 of 1923; Nos. 26 and 59 of 1924; No. 21 of 1926; No. 33 of 1930; Nos. 44 and 46 of 1933; No. 38 of 1935; No. 2 of 1938; No. 4 of 1940; No. 3 of 1941; No. 20 of 1943; No. 23 of 1945; Nos. 22 and 37 of 1946; No. 39 of 1947 and No. 17 of 1948).

The necessity for this increased Estimate is due in the main to the modification during the year of the Employment Period Orders. The original Estimate of the cost of unemployment assistance was based on the assumption that the Employment Period Orders made during 1948 would be similar to the Orders made during 1947. As was revealed during the year, however, that was not the position. In 1948 the Second Employment Period Order was for a lesser period than in 1947. The Order of 1947 debarred occupiers of land exceeding £2 in valuation from applying for or receiving unemployment assistance benefit during the currency of the Employment Period Order.

MainHeading.P: The 1948 Employment Period Order raised the valuation limit of occupiers of land from £2 to £4, and thus enabled those with holdings of land of a valuation not exceeding £4 to apply for unemployment assistance benefit during the currency of the Orders, whereas in 1947 they could not have applied for that assistance if the valuation of their land exceeded £2.

A supplementary cause of the necessity for this Estimate is the fact that the Second Employment Period Order in 1948 was for three weeks less than it was in 1947 and thus three weeks' additional expenditure on unemployment assistance had to be met arising out of that cause. It may be taken that the cost of the modification of the Employment Period Orders in 1948, as compared with 1947, was in the region, as far as we can estimate, of £120,000. The increased cost of unemployment assistance during the year may also be contributed to by reason of the fact that persons who were previously unable to obtain unemployment assistance were entitled to apply for, and to qualify for, that assistance during the past year.

Another contributory cause arose out of the fact that during 1948 the new Social Welfare Act enabled persons who are living in houses in rural areas which were owned by urban authorities to obtain unemployment assistance benefit at the urban rates instead of the rural rates which previously obtained. It is the combination of all these factors that is responsible, in the main, for the Supplementary Estimate which is now necessary in order to finance the service to the end of the financial year.

Speaker.P: Every Deputy in the House knows that unemployment has increased, and I am sure every Deputy is disturbed by that knowledge. However disturbed we may have been heretofore, we have much more reason for it now in view of the speech made by the Minister for Social Welfare. Does the Minister seriously expect us to believe that the whole of the £375,000 required, in addition to the sum already voted this year for the payment of unemployment assistance, is due, solely, to the causes that he mentioned? Are these additional unemployed workers recorded on the register not entitled to unemployment assistance? Are they not getting unemployment assistance? Is not a substantial part, if not the larger part, of that sum required to pay unemployment assistance to workers who were in employment in the previous year and who, it was anticipated when the Estimate was being prepared, would also be in employment this year?

A 20 per cent. increase in the cost of unemployment assistance cannot be explained away by a reference to minor changes in the scope of the Employment Period Orders, or in the regulations governing the payment of unemployment assistance. We know that the live register of unemployed workers has shown an increase for every month since February, 1948, with one exception, the month of November last, and that over the whole 12 months' period there has been an average increase of 6,700.

MainHeading.P: That is the primary reason, I submit, why an increased Estimate for unemployment assistance is now required, and the Minister would have been far franker with the House if he had given that reason. I am also perturbed at the Minister's attitude, because I have always believed that if the problem of unemployment here is to be tackled adequately, if public support is to be got for the measures necessary for dealing with it, whether they involve increased taxation, the regulation of trade or interference with private interests, we cannot hope to get it in adequate degree unless we inform the public fully of the position, and the gravity of the position. I know that there is, in some minds, the idea that the problem of unemployment can be disposed of by concealing it. Before I became Minister for Industry and Commerce in 1932, my predecessor tried these tactics. He had suppressed the unemployment statistics and so arranged matters in his Department that it was not possible to extract from them, even by way of Dáil question, accurate information as to the number of unemployed in the country. I reversed that policy, and I think I was wise in doing so, even though the reversal brought the other problem. I felt that if we were to get here in this country the right outlook on the problem, we had to bring its gravity home to every citizen, and to that end we arranged not merely for the republication of the weekly unemployment statistics, but set up this inter-departmental committee, which publishes every year a report on the trend of employment and unemployment and which gives a comprehensive interpretation of the whole picture for public information.

I suggest to the Minister for Social Welfare that he is on the wrong line of policy if he seriously intends that effective action should be taken to deal with the growing problem of unemployment in trying to pretend to the public that it does not exist, or is less serious than the public know it to be. I know that during the course of the year he gave statistics which were intended to convey the impression that unemployment was decreasing and that emigration was decreasing. I am sure he did not himself believe that interpretation to be accurate.

Speaker.P: Will the Deputy refer me to the occasion?

The Minister gave information concerning the sales of unemployment insurance stamps which was intended to suggest that the problem of unemployment was contracting, and he gave far more dishonest information concerning the movements of passengers in and out of the country in the height of the tourist season for the purpose of conveying the suggestion that emigration was declining. If the Minister believes that, then it is about time that some of the back bench members of the Party told him what is happening in the country. I do not want to exaggerate the picture but I know that there are parts of the West of Ireland—and I mention Kerry and Mayo in particular—where the exodus of the population at the present time is as great as it was in the year after the civil war—in 1924. Last week there could have been seen at the railway stations in these counties the crowds of people, which we saw in that year saying farewell to their relatives departing for the emigrant ship.

MainHeading.P: I have never pretended that there is an easy solution for unemployment or for emigration. I have never suggested, as others suggested, that there was some secret method which, if applied, would solve these problems overnight. But when I am faced here with an Estimate for £375,000 to pay out more unemployment assistance and interpret that Estimate as meaning that, instead of moving towards a solution of these problems, we are moving away from them, then I feel obliged to remind the Minister that both he and his colleagues professed in the most specific terms to have a solution for these problems which could be operated overnight; and, if they have that solution, is it not high time that they produced it?
On the last occasion that I came here with an Estimate for the Department of Industry and Commerce my successor used the following words:—

“I said here 12 months ago, and I want to repeat it now, that without the slightest trouble every able-bodied man and woman in this country could be put into useful work to-morrow morning. There is not a shadow of doubt about that.” (Volume 105, column 847 of Dáil Debates.)

The man who spoke those words is now Minister for Industry and Commerce. He is now in a position to put into operation whatever ideas he had in mind when he spoke those words in 1947. Why has he not done so? Has he endeavoured to do so and found that his ideas were not so good? Has he been prevented by his Cabinet colleagues from applying his ideas? What is the explanation of the fact that instead of having every able-bodied man and woman in this country put into useful work overnight, we have to record a substantial and growing increase in unemployment and in emigration? Again, at column 950 of the same volume there is the following:—

“When we look for expanding employment a most doleful picture confronts us. Emigration is still draining the country of its manhood and its womanhood. The most striking aspect of the problem of emigration is that, although the war in Europe is over for two years, and although we ought now to be setting about the task of reconstruction, and the task of economic and agricultural expansion, the fact remains that we are still exporting from the country men and women on a scale comparable to, and, in some instances, greater than, the rate of exportation during the war period.”
I have no doubt the Minister recognises the phraseology; it is his own. He went on, in column 952, to say:—

“I do not blame these unfortunate people seeking employment in Great Britain. It is their only alternative to the workhouse or to beggarly pittances. They have been driven there by economic conditions. No sense of love of work in Britain induces them to go; no sense of love for British food standards, no sense of affection for a different concept of life. They go for one reason only, that employment there is a passport to the means of sustaining themselves and providing for their families at home.”
The flow of emigration in 1947 was serious. It gave the Government then in office grounds for concern, and urged them to adopt various emergency devices in an effort to check it.

Speaker.P: How does emigration arise on this Supplementary Estimate?
I think it will be agreed that emigration is only one side of the problem of unemployment.
The items in this are unemployment assistance and supplements, special register of agricultural and turf workers. Those are the only matters that I can see.
It seems more appropriate to an Industry and Commerce Estimate, I suggest.
If emigration is out of the picture I shall confine myself to unemployment.
All I am asking for is the necessary moneys to pay benefits which are provided for by statute.
But why is an additional sum necessary? Surely the Dáil is entitled to ask that when voting moneys.
It might be discussed on the Industry and Commerce Estimate but not on an Estimate for Social Welfare.
I suggest that there is no more appropriate time to discuss the growing problem of unemployment than on a Supplementary Estimate for unemployment assistance.
But this is a Supplementary Estimate with special sub-heads.
I am not clear as to how unemployment comes under the charge of the Minister for Social Welfare.
I do not think the Minister for Social Welfare is very much concerned about it.
You did not give too much evidence of that yourself.

If the Minister wants me to concede that we did not end unemployment, I agree fully. I think that we made very substantial progress in the matter of increasing the number of people in work but the progress did not go fast enough or far enough to achieve the objectives we had in view. However, so long as we were going in the right direction, I did not mind. Now we are going in the wrong direction and, before we are presented with another bill for further unemployment assistance payments because of a further increase in unemployment, I think the Minister for Social Welfare has an obligation to bring the facts to the notice of whichever Minister is responsible so that some steps can be taken to check it.

MainHeading.P: If, however, we cannot discuss on this Supplementary Estimate the Government's failure to check the increase in unemployment and emigration, the failure to put into operation the plan which the present Minister for Industry and Commerce told us could solve unemployment in 24 hours, let us consider the precise significance of the Estimate that the Minister has given us. It is well known to every Deputy that the increase in unemployment which occurred during the past year and which is still occurring is located mainly in the rural areas. So far as industrial employment is concerned, we note from the most recent figures published in the Trade Journal that between March and September last year there was no diminution; there was in fact a small increase of 493 in the number of persons engaged in the manufacture of transportable goods. One might express disappointment that the year 1948, the year in which the most serious shortages of the war years ended, the year to which we were looking forward as a year of great industrial recovery and expansion, should have been able to record an addition of only 493 to the number employed in industry.

If there has been this increase in unemployment, averaging 6,700 per month, and if that increase is mainly located in the rural areas, the Minister must be aware of the fact that all the indications are that next year the increase will be greater still. I do not know and cannot estimate what may be the effect on rural employment of special Government schemes for drainage or anything else but the indications are that employment on the land and employment in rural occupations is steadily declining. There are Deputies on every side of the House coming from counties where it was never the practice to employ agricultural workers on a temporary or seasonal basis who will say that that is now becoming the practice and that workers are being employed by farmers only as and when required.

Speaker.P: I do not want to interrupt the Deputy, but the Minister for Social Welfare is, by statute, supposed to provide money for the relief of unemployment by means of unemployment assistance and unemployment insurance. I do not think it is within the province of the Minister for Social Welfare to provide employment.

May I point out, in correction, that it is not the function of the Minister for Social Welfare to provide the money for the payment of unemployment assistance; it is the function of the Dáil. The Minister cannot provide the money unless the Dáil votes it, and the Dáil is being asked to vote it now.
Unemployed people must get the money if they comply with certain conditions.

Certainly. But when the Minister comes to the Dáil and asks us, as the taxpayers' representatives, to provide him with an additional £270,000 because of the increase of unemployment, surely we are entitled to ask him what measures are being taken, or are in contemplation, to avoid the repetition of that increased unemployment next year.

May I say that if the Deputy is allowed to do that this year, it is more than we were allowed to do when we were in opposition, on a Vote of this kind; on a Vote for Industry and Commerce, yes, but not on a Vote of this kind?

I do not think I am wrong in saying that on such occasions as it was necessary to produce a Supplementary Estimate for unemployment assistance and unemployment insurance arising out of an unanticipated increase in unemployment, the Dáil did discuss it, and discussed it fairly fully.
Not on a Social Welfare Vote, and I would ask the Deputy to give me evidence if it did happen. On a Vote for Industry and Commerce, yes.

I would like to remind the Minister that the Ministry for Social Welfare was only set up in 1947. Prior to that, this unemployment assistance and insurance service was administered by the Department of Industry and Commerce.

The Deputy wants to proceed as if it were never set up and discuss industry and commerce matters. But if the Deputy has his speech ready, there is no reason why he should not deliver it if the Chair lets him.

I do not think the Deputy can discuss unemployment on this vote. It is not the function of the Minister for Social Welfare to provide employment; it is the function of some other Minister. If the Deputy looks it up, he will find that this comes purely under the Unemployment Assistance Act of 1933.

I fully realise that as far as the statutory functions go the Minister has to pay unemployment assistance to persons who are entitled to it in accordance with the Act, but we are asked for a supplementary sum for that purpose and surely we are entitled to take note of the reasons why that supplementary sum is required. Personally, I would have been far less concerned with discussing the matter if the Minister had been a little more frank with the Dáil in his introductory speech. He knows as well as I do that the reasons he gave for coming here to seek a Supplementary Estimate do not explain the whole or the half of the magnitude of the situation.
I cannot see what the Deputy is endeavouring to raise on this matter.

If Deputy Lemass feels that he is entitled to discuss unemployment on this, then as a corollary he may discuss why particular people are unemployed or why people are unemployed in a particular industry with the result that I might appear to be held responsible for a falling off in employment in a particular industry. My functions are clear and simple. It is accepted by the legislature that there will be unemployment, that people will be unemployment, and my function is to provide rates of benefit at the scales laid down by statute. I have no other function. I cannot, as Minister for Social Welfare, put one single person in employment in industry, agriculture or commerce. I am not permitted to enter that field of national activity. My function is to administer the statutes laid down by the Dáil. I would like you to say, Sir, whether this discussion is to cover the whole field of unemployment.

I will content myself by saying that I would like the Government to consider the advisability of giving the Dáil an opportunity to discuss the whole field of unemployment, for this is a matter which is becoming one of urgent concern.
I will admit that.

Perhaps I can relate some of the observations which I would like to put to the Dáil to sub-head H of the Supplementary Estimate. The special register for agricultural and turf workers has been abolished. The register was established at a time when we thought it necessary during the war to impose restrictions upon the emigration of persons skilled in agriculture, or of turf workers. In justice to those who were so restricted, and who might, nevertheless, be from time to time unemployed, we felt that the restrictions should be accompanied by administrative arrangements which ensured to these persons the payment of unemployment assistance at higher than ordinary rates, and the payment of unemployment assistance in circumstances in which they would not be entitled to receive it under ordinary law. The necessity for the special register for agricultural and turf workers, while these restrictions were in force, arose from the seasonal nature of the employment of many agricultural workers. Roughly about half of the workers employed for wages in agriculture in past years were temporary employees, while the other half were classified as permanent.

May I point out to you, Sir, and to the Deputy, that this service was terminated in December, 1947, and is, therefore, not normally on the Estimate of this year? How the Deputy is going to discuss a scheme which he abolished himself I do not know.

I was going to urge upon the Minister the advisability of restoring it, and I do so because, to my knowledge, the proportion between permanent and temporary employees in agriculture is being distorted. I, perhaps, would not be in order in discussing the reasons operating to that end, but that that is happening is well known to everybody, and if we are to give a new impetus to agriculture by reason of an intensification of the seasonality of agricultural employment, then, as an immediate measure for coping with that situation while longer-term plans are being worked out, the reintroduction of that register might be considered. The actual financial cost in the past was never very considerable; the organisation to administer it is there and it has the necessary experience to bring the scheme into operation with very little delay.

The total amount which is required to meet the increased cost of unemployment assistance is £375,000 but the actual amount of additional money required is only £26,000. It may be no harm to remind Deputies that one of the reasons why it is possible to face this heavy increase in the cost of unemployment assistance without imposing a corresponding charge upon the Exchequer is the fact that by legislation during the course of the year the Minister for Social Welfare transferred the cost of cash supplements under the unemployment assistance scheme from the Exchequer to the insured contributors. That has brought into the Exchequer in the period in which it has been in force the sum of £178,000. It is not an insignificant contribution by the employed workers to defray the cost of supporting, if one can use that term in relation to unemployment assistance, the growing number of unemployed workers.

MainHeading.P: Sub-head G sets out the Appropriations-in-Aid. I note that under Section 3 of the Unemployment Insurance Act, 1933, a further sum of £36,800 is required. I think that section of the 1933 Act, which amended a section of the earlier Act of 1920, relates to the contribution towards the cost of administration of the unemployment insurance scheme, which is met by the Unemployment Insurance Fund. The contribution, if my recollection serves me correctly, is three-twentieths of the income. If that is so and if this increased contribution from the fund is due to an expansion of the income of the fund, I should like the Minister to explain to me, if he can, the extent to which that expansion of income is due to the changes in the law which were made last year and to what extent it might be attributable to an increase in insurable employment such as would occur if private turf producers were transferred to temporary road schemes. We know that the number of insured contributors was increased last year when the scope of the Unemployment Insurance Act was extended to include non-manual workers with incomes up to £500 per annum. I do not know that the Minister attempted to give any advance estimate of the number of additional contributors likely to be created by that change. I am anxious that that figure should be brought out and that the Minister should do so now, if possible. In the past we endeavoured to measure fluctuations in insurable employment by calculating the average weekly number of employed from the number of insurance stamps sold. Clearly, any similar calculations in respect of 1948 will not be capable of valid comparison with earlier years because of this addition to the classes of persons who are required to pay contributions.

Speaker.P: The Deputy appreciates that that only came into operation on the 1st of last October.
Therefore, any calculation for 1948 will have to make some allowance——
You can only make the calculation, surely, when the stamped cards come back and you see who is insurable.

There is available to the Minister a less reliable index in advance of that date, which is, in fact, published in the Trade Journal, namely, the number of sheets of stamps sold—and they have to be purchased before they can be affixed.
But you cannot get that information since October.
I agree.
Therefore, the information the Deputy wants is not really available.
If I am not making a mistake the Trade Journal publishes the figure up to the end of November.
Even that will not give you a——
No, I am wrong. The figure is only published up to the end of September, but as the issue of the journal is for December, 1948, I was hoping that the Minister would by now, March, have later figures.
They did not publish them.

I take it that the next issue of the Trade Journal is in course of preparation at the present time. However, if the Minister cannot give the information now, that is too bad. I think, nevertheless, that he himself will appreciate the importance of publishing such information as will enable persons who study the statistics available to calculate to what extent increased contributions under the unemployment insurance scheme are to be attributable to an actual bona fide increase in insurable employment or to expansion of the number of persons required to make contributions or to the increase in contributions for which the legislation last year provided.

MainHeading.P: I see that the Minister anticipates a deficiency in the contribution from county boroughs and urban area councils under the Unemployment Assistance Act. The House is, I think, aware that the rates of unemployment assistance payable in boroughs and urban areas are higher than those obtaining in rural areas, but, to offset that advantage to these areas, their ratepayers are required to make a contribution to the cost of unemployment assistance. One would have thought that there would have been no difficulty in calculating to a penny the amount to be received from an urban area or borough on foot of that provision. I should like the Minister to explain how it is that a deficiency of £9,000 is envisaged.

I would have said a lot more, Sir, if you had not confined me to the particular sub-heads of the Estimate. I hope I have said enough to convince the Minister for Social Welfare that, if his present function may be limited to the submission of this supplementary Vote to the Dail, there is a matter of such grave importance that the Dáil should have an opportunity of discussing it soon.

Speaker.P: I think Deputy Lemass can scarcely have been unaware of the fact that he was taking liberties with all previous procedures when he attempted to discuss such wide problems as emigration and unemployment generally on an Estimate for a Department which, he must know, is not empowered to deal with unemployment or emigration but which merely administers services which are consequent on the fact that we have unemployment and emigration. We have had unemployment for a long time and we have had emigration for a long time.
Not as much as we have now.

Well, we shall see. One would think that the problem of unemployment was a new problem to hear Deputy Lemass talk about it. The plain fact of the matter is that on the 5th February, 1948, there were 78,419 persons on the live register, with a Fianna Fáil Government in office, and not in office for 12 months, but——
Sixteen years.
This was the result, as Deputy Little rightly points out, after 16 years——
Good old figure that—16 years.

I thank the Deputy for reminding me. There is no need for anybody to raise his eyebrows and to say that we have a large number of unemployed to-day. We had a very large number of unemployed when the Deputy's Party was going out of office last year.
That is not denied.
What is the idea of all the annoyance when I give you your own figure?
Not a bit.

I am glad you take it so philosophically. Bear this in mind. That figure would have been very much higher in February last year were it not for the fact that quite a goodly number of people were put into employment at the end of 1947 and the early weeks of 1948. I am not at all convinced, from looking at the step-up in employment during that period, that some folk who were responsible for putting them into employment had not their eyes on the fact that the 4th February, 1948, was polling day.
The Minister had better not pursue that line.
Call every day a polling day——
Have you not had enough of polling day? Is your trouble not that you have not been well since the last polling day?
Call every day a polling day and give the men work.

We are carrying on the register this year, to some extent, people who can now qualify for benefit under the Act passed last year and who could not previously qualify. I do not know to what extent that is so, but we are carrying on the register, to some extent, some persons who were previously deprived of the right to claim unemployment assistance because they would not join the Construction Corps. These people were previously told that, if they were unemployed, they must join the Construction Corps and would not be allowed benefit if eligible to join the corps. The Construction Corps not being in existence now, these people can claim benefit and they come on to the register in the employment exchanges and branch offices throughout the country. To that extent, therefore, they add to the number of persons registered as unemployed.
But they were unemployed.

I do not want to conceal in the slightest the fact that we have an unemployment problem and must face up to it. No matter what Government is in office, it is morally bound to face up to that problem. I do not want to underestimate it, nor do I want in any way to suggest that it is not a serious problem. The very fact that there are idle men and women in the country where work is available for them is national waste, and I should like to see the problem, because it is national waste, tackled with vigour, with courage and with enthusiasm. My views on the problem and the way in which it might be dealt with are well known. I hope, however, that some of the schemes already announced this year will make a considerable contribution to easing our difficulties in that respect. The scheme under which £40,000,000 will be spent on field and river drainage for a period of ten years ought not only to provide substantial employment but should provide it in areas where the problem is greater than it is in others.

MainHeading.P: A calculation which I made the other day for my own information revealed that approximately 28 to 30 per cent. of our unemployment assistance applicants come from the four areas, Kerry, Mayo, Galway and Donegal. Out of about 48,000 unemployment assistance applicants in the whole country, about 20,000 come from these four areas alone. I think that, so far as employment is concerned, the problem in these areas is not a problem of industrial employment but an agrarian problem in its roots. You have in these areas small landholders trying to live on small patches of land. There are no industries and when there is no work for them on the small and hard patches of land on which they try to live, they come to the employment exchange and try to get there the benefits which are provided under the Unemployment Assistance Acts. The remedy in these cases is either to industrialise the area, and Deputy Lemass ought to know the difficulties in doing that, after 16 years in office, or to provide some kind of agricultural employment for these people. But there again the serious problem presents itself because of the quality of the land in the areas where the claims for unemployment assistance are highest.

Speaker.P: I allowed Deputy Lemass to go a good way in enlarging the scope of this discussion. I have allowed the Minister to go as far as I propose to allow him in enlarging its scope. Perhaps he would now come to the Estimate.

I do not desire to follow Deputy Lemass further along that line, except to say that, in many cases and over large areas of the country, the payment of unemployment assistance, as, I think, Deputy Lemass will agree from his previous experience, is a concession to life to people who live in these areas, because there is no employment for them in these areas and unemployment assistance is a means of sustaining life there; but it is not an accurate measure or a measure in any sense of industrial employment. If it is a measure of anything, it is a measure of the width and the depth of the agrarian problem in these areas. I do not want to be facetious by quoting against Deputy Lemass some of his own hopes in respect of the relief of the problem of unemployment. I do not want to go back to the merry old days when all the emigrants were to be brought back.
I never promised to settle it in 24 hours, like my successor.
Which successor?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce, who said that he would put every able-bodied man to work in 24 hours.
The Deputy will remember his salad days around 1931 and 1932 when he was going to bring back the emigrants from America.
That was a Cumann na nGaedheal distortion. I never said it.
I think I have the leaflet.
There is no money in this Estimate for bringing back emigrants.

No emigrants came back, so it was not necessary to provide money, as Deputy Lemass knows well. It is generally agreed that, so long as we have unemployment, it is necessary for the Legislature to provide money to finance the Acts which the Legislature passes for extending relief to those who have necessarily to apply for it, and I need not widen the scope of the discussion, if there is general agreement on that point.

Deputy Lemass asked why it was anticipated that there would be a fall in the remittances due from the borough councils. I understand that the deficiency in the receipts from these councils is due to the fact that some of the moneys which we expected to receive this year were in fact paid last year and the local authorities are not going to pay a second time. That makes it necessary, therefore, to anticipate a reduced income from the borough councils for the current year.

MainHeading.P: He raised the question of the restoration of the agricultural register. My predecessor in office found it necessary to abolish that register, because he felt it was not being widely availed of. Even though it was abolished when I went into office, I looked at it very critically to see if it was worth while restoring it, but I am afraid that all the evidence which convinced my predecessor that he should abolish it was present, and reinforced my view that its retention was not justified because of the extremely small number of people availing of the arrangement. I do not see any evidence, nor is any evidence available to my Department, that the reconstitution of the register would induce people to register in the way previously provided, and Deputy Lemass, I am afraid, must accept the view that the abolition which my predecessor thought desirable must still hold, because I see no evidence of any likelihood, if it were reinstituted, that it would be availed of by employers on the one hand, or agricultural workers on the other. During the year, whenever a shortage of agricultural workers was notified to the Department, we endeavoured not merely to put agricultural employers in touch with the neighbouring employment exchanges but also to relay the needs of farmers to neighbouring exchanges, in the hope that, in that way, persons seeking employment in agriculture might be tempted, by payment of reasonable wages, to migrate within the country for agricultural employment wherever that employment was available.
Vote put and agreed to.

MainHeading.Title: Committee on Finance. - Vote 64—Army Pensions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Dr. O'Higgins) Thomas Francis (Jnr.) O'Higgins
Speaker.P: I move:—

That a supplementary sum not exceeding £30,900 be granted to defray the Charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending 31st March, 1949, for Wound and Disability Pensions, Further Pensions and Married Pensions, Allowances and Gratuities (No. 26 of 1923, No. 12 of 1927, No. 24 of 1932, No. 15 of 1937, No. 2 of 1941, No. 14 of 1943 and No. 3 of 1946); Military Service Pensions, Allowances and Gratuities (No. 48 of 1924, No. 26 of 1932, No. 43 of 1934, No. 33 of 1938, No. 5 of 1944 and Nos. 11 and 34 of 1945); Pensions, Allowances and Gratuities (No. 37 of 1936 and No. 9 of 1948); Payments in respect of Compensation for Members of the Local Defence Force (No. 19 of 1946); and for sundry contributions and Expenses in respect thereof, etc.; and for an ExtraStatutory Grant.

MainHeading.P: The circumstances that made it necessary to bring in this Supplementary Estimate as shown in the White Paper are as follows:—Under sub-head C, £4,000 is needed to cover the arrears of wound and disability pensions which come in the course of payment during the year. When the original Estimate was drafted in the winter of 1947 it was estimated that there was an average of four months to be met. In fact, that average has been greatly exceeded and in some cases there were arrears of pensions falling for payment up to as many as three years. Under sub-head G, there is a sum of £10,300 falling for payment which was not reckoned on this year, the reason being that, in connection with the abatement clauses of the Military Service Pensions Act, the abatement in the case of Civic Guards was heretofore reckoned on their pay and allowances of various kinds. This year it was found that that was incorrect and that we were only entitled to make the abatement on the pay of the Guards without taking into account the various allowances. Therefore, under this sub-head we have to make a refund in the abatement, going back as far as 20 years. The amount of money involved in that refund to members of the Garda Síochána is £10,300. In addition to that, there is £5,000 in respect of the deficit on current abatement. It was reckoned that under the appropriate section there would be a reduction of £28,000 and in the working year it transpired that that Estimate was not fulfilled. The abatement came to only £23,000. The balance, £2,700, is simply a normal variation in the expenditure under this sub-head. The small figure, £131, under sub-head K is required to implement the abatement clause in connection with the Connaught Rangers Act, which was introduced in the course of last year.

Under sub-head M, Special Allowances, when framing the Estimate for the financial year coming to an end, it was calculated that the number of people falling for special allowances would be at the rate of 20 a month and that the average allocation made to each of the 20 would be £62. In the working of the scheme throughout the year, we found that we were dealing with and putting through 40 a month and that the average allowance to each person was £65. That accounts for the extra sum asked for under that particular heading. That makes a total of £43,000 odd required under this Supplementary Estimate and there is a drawback under other sub-heads amounting to £12,000, leaving a balance of the amount I mentioned at the outset.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. A. Byrne Mr. A. Byrne
Speaker.P: Might I ask the Minister a question? Did he give any consideration to his promise of last year regarding the men who went out on an earlier Act—I think it was the 1946 Act —who were induced to go out, I think, on the 2nd September and where it occurred that immediately afterwards there was an increase in the pension rates to the men who remained on? When the matter was raised by Deputy Cowan and myself, and I think Deputy Cosgrave, the Minister promised that he would go into the matter and asked us not to press him until he had time to consider all the facts. There are three or four hundred men who gave 21-23 years' service and who went out on a smaller pension than those who remained on and went out three months later. I forget the dates, as I was not prepared for this just now. I remember the Minister himself being asked by Deputy Cowan and myself, and I think Deputy Cosgrave, to give these men consideration, and the Minister promised that he would consider whether he could introduce amending legislation to deal with the matter and include them.
The Deputy cannot advocate legislation on this Estimate. There is no money for that in this Vote. The Deputy can raise the point on the main vote, but not on this one.
The Deputy can raise it on the Defence Forces Pensions Scheme.

A Supplementary Estimate of this kind has become a more or less normal procedure in this House, due mainly to the reasons which the Minister himself has explained. Looking through the Estimate, there is nothing that I can say very well on any of these points. I am glad, naturally, to see that the special allowances have been increased to the extent that they have been increased, and the explanation which the Minister has given in respect of sub-head G accounts largely for the sum required under that sub-head.

MainHeading.P: The Minister will remember that, on the Estimate proper, which was discussed during the present financial year, I made reference to two matters to which I asked him to give sympathetic consideration. I think the Minister himself promised to inquire actively and vigorously into the particular point which I made. Having fully explained them on the Estimate proper, there is no necessity for me to go over them again. One referred to the question of the forfeiture of pensions. The Minister is aware of the circumstances in which these military service pensions can be forfeited. The idea originally was probably quite all right but a lot of things that appear quite all right very often work out all wrong when they come to work out in practice. While I was acting as Minister for Defence I came across at least two or three cases in which I felt an injustice was done to the unfortunate people who came under those particular cases which I have in mind.

Speaker.P: Will the Deputy say whether they would require new legislation?
It would require Ministerial examination. That is all I am asking and that is all I did ask for.

MainHeading.P: The other point which I referred to was that in which the means test was operating very hardly against certain of the recipients of that allowance. Again I outlined one particular case in which the hardship was, to my mind, very extreme. A sister was supporting her brother and because the brother was securing that means of livelihood from the sister his means were assessed at some extraordinary figure which reduced the special allowance to a niggardly sum of something like 7/- a week. As I said on that occasion, neither the Government nor any Deputy in this House ever visualised that the ideas which we had in mind when we brought in that legislation would ever operate in that way. The Minister promised at that time to look into these two cases. Of course, I have not raised the matter since and from that point of view the Minister could not have given me any information, but I am availing of the opportunity which this Supplementary Estimate provides to ask the Minister if he has been good enough to take any action in the matter and, if so, what was the result of the action.

Speaker.P: The Chair's difficulty is whether that opportunity does arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: This Supplementary Estimate deals with the question of a large sum of money that covers the adjustment of the abatement of pensions. In other words, it covers a good deal of money that has to be refunded to members of the Garda Síochána for the pay which the Minister has discovered through his scrutiny was not correct. I should like to ask the Minister if he has considered the plea which I made and which, I think, Deputy Traynor made on the main Estimate—particularly in view of the statement which the Minister has made now that instead of saving, as he had thought, £28,000, they had, in fact, recouped only £23,000. On the question of the abatement of pensions is he now in a position to state whether the Government would consider the question of abolishing the pensions completely? I should like to take this opportunity, and I am entitled to do so in view of the fact that the Supplementary Estimate deals with moneys that arise under the abatement of pensions to——
The Deputy is entitled to deal with the precise matters under the sub-head and not to advocate new legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: The matter under the sub-head deals with a refund of money that goes back over 20 years and I do not think it is necessary to advocate new legislation to deal with this matter. Only a Ministerial Order is needed to effect this. On that basis, I urge it on the Minister, in view of the fact that the main Estimate will be coming shortly before the House, to make some statement, if he can, on the abatement in general.
Provided it does not require new legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: It will not.

I am very pleased to see an increase of £21,000 in the amount for special allowances. I think that shows that quite a considerable number of persons entitled to those special allowances are receiving them now. I think Deputies on all sides of the House will be glad to know that the machinery of this Act is being administered in such a way that an additional sum of £21,000 is necessary to provide these supplementary allowances this year.

I am also glad to know that the matter of the abatement of pensions in regard to allowances as distinct from the salaries of Gardaí has been adjusted. That was a bone of contention for quite a considerable period. It was a claim that members of the Gardaí made over a long period and I am glad to know that that is being satisfactorily settled and that only the salary will be liable to abatement while this business of abatement lasts.

While there have been declarations made by the Minister from time to time in answer to questions here and in answer to deputations that he was considering as sympathetically as he could the claims of a number of people for military service pensions who are not now in receipt of those pensions, I can see at once that legislation will be necessary for that purpose. I am not availing of this opportunity to——
The Deputy seems to be.
No, I am availing of the opportunity to do no more than to ask the Minister, when he is ready, to repeat his promise that the matter is still under his consideration.
If the Minister were allowed and in order.
I think he will be in order.

I should like to ask the Minister a question. When will he exercise the prerogative which Deputy Collins informs us he has by Ministerial Order to allow a further number of persons to apply for medals?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: On a point of order, I did not say that.
The Minister promised the House on a previous occasion that he was proposing to have this done.
That is new legislation too.
There is no money provided for medals.
I am informed by Deputy Collins that it can be done by Ministerial Order or otherwise.
There is no money for medals.

Will the Minister give us some information on that matter because it is a problem that we are asked about every day of the week? I think the Minister is aware of that, too. He might also give us the information when, by Ministerial Order, he proposes to allow applications for service pensions.
There is no money here for that purpose.
He does not want money to make Ministerial Orders.
The question does not arise at all. I am not hearing the Deputy further on that.
I am not pursuing the matter further.

I should like to know from the Minister, as regards special allowances, if anything can be done about the age and the means test, so that people may qualify. I think the Minister will agree that people of 68 or 69 years are hardly capable of selfsupport. We have had a few cases like that in Cork and when questions were put the reply invariably was that these people had been found capable of supporting themselves. I am sure the Minister will agree that nobody will employ a man of 68 or 69 years. Such a person is incapable of getting employment sufficient to support him.

MainHeading.P: As regards the means test, I do not know if the Minister can interfere there. Perhaps he can through the medium of the Ministerial Order that Deputy Collins spoke of. The means test in connection with that special allowance is extra severe, especially for people with children. If there is a boy or girl working up to 18 years of age all the earnings are taken into account as income. When the child is over 18 it is only the profit from the earnings after the cost of support is deducted that is taken into consideration. With the old age pensions and other means tests the position is entirely different. I do not know whether the Minister can do anything about it. I merely draw his attention to the hardships involved. A few cases were brought to my notice recently. People could not draw a special allowance on account of the earnings of their children; they could not do anything until the children reached 18 years.

Speaker.P: I am thankful to Deputies for the way they discussed this particular Supplementary Estimate. There is evidence all round that any suggestions made were certainly made with the idea of helping on the work and assisting the unfortunate people who have to depend on Votes such as this for assistance.

With regard to the special allowances and the regulations governing them, there are two things very definitely and explicitly laid down in the Act, matters over which no Minister has any control short of amending the legislation. A person must be definitely and permanently incapable of earning a livelihood because of bodily infirmity. That is a matter for a medical board and not a matter for any Minister. No Minister can interfere with the findings of such a board. Most medical people, if not all, are weighted on the side of the patient. Most medical men are oversympathetic as between a patient and the State. It is on the findings of the medical board, and solely on those findings, that incapacity is decided on. It is merely a political accident——
Perhaps the Minister will excuse me for intervening? I think they take the age of 70 as being the qualifying age for the special allowance. Would the medical board be induced to accept 65 years?

The medical board is tied down to finding the person incapable, by reason of health or his physical condition, of earning a livelihood and no Minister can interfere with the finding of the board. If the medical board sent to a Minister a report that an allIreland footballer was unfit to earn his livelihood because of physical incapacity, that is the end of it, as far as the Minister goes. The man gets his allowance even though he could break the Minister's neck in a tussle. The Act lays it down that it is a matter for the board, and the Minister is powerless to interfere. All my information, and all the information available to my predecessor, is that those medical people approach that work in a sympathetic frame of mind.

I admit cases come along that any individual Minister would rather he got another report on, but we have to put up with the report we get. All the Minister can do, if he thinks it is a fairly hard case, is to get it reviewed 12 months later. That is laid down in the Act, that the case can be reopened that day 12 months, but it cannot be reopened within the period of 12 months. Both my predecessor and myself, since this Act started to operate, reopened a great number of cases at the end of the 12 months' period.

With regard to the means test, in order to save the time of the Dáil I read through the introductory statement rather rapidly and I gave only the bigger items. The reason that the average of £62 in the original Estimate was raised to £65 was that any modifications that could be made in a means test were made in the course of the year arising out of things raised here last year. There have been certain modifications in the means test, with the result that the average allowance has been raised by £3 per head.
Does that mean that the inspector is taking a more liberal view?

I have not the details at my fingers' ends, but there were a number of the things taken into account when ascertaining means that were challenged by the Department of Defence. We did not win all along the front, but certain of these things were conceded.

Will those who were in receipt of allowances before the modification of the means test took place be recouped any moneys that were kept from them by reason of the fact that the means test was, in the first instance, so severe.
No. Any alteration in the means test would apply only as from the date the alteration was agreed to.

Would the Minister consider that fair? The amount involved would not be very large and surely it would be only dealing out justice for the recipients of these allowances that they should all be treated on the same basis? There are certain people in receipt of that allowance or a certain portion of it, due to a severe means test. Then another individual comes along later and because this test was modified he receives a higher allowance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: Is not the Deputy's sympathy a bit belated?
Will the Minister reconsider the position of the individuals who originally had the allowance and make good the moneys they were deprived of?

I do not think there is any question of inspectors in connection with the schemes. Everybody is endeavouring to do the maximum amount of justice and the mere fact that certain things that went to the make up of means were removed from a certain date for everybody was a big concession; and the chances are that you would not get such a concession if you were to make it retrospective. In any case it did not take anything from anybody but it gave a certain small amount——
I agree, but nevertheless the fact remains.

Deputy Traynor raised the question of forfeiture. I agree with him absolutely that there is an unduly harsh continuing penalty on certain unfortunate individuals because of the law which governs forfeiture at the moment. That particular question of giving to the appropriate Minister the right after a certain lapse of time to review forfeiture is actually under Governmental consideration at the moment. I do not know what the outcome will be, but it is under consideration.

Deputy Byrne put a question as to the different scales of pensions applicable to people who left the Army on certain dates. I think that owing to the confusion created by the multiplicity of small Acts dealing with the Army the Deputy was under a misunderstanding. That does not come within this group of Army pensions at all. A promise was, however, made to the House to have the matter considered. That promise was kept and the matter has got very, very careful consideration. Whatever the outcome may be, it is being considered. But none of us has our own way absolutely in this world. Perhaps it would be a better place if we had.

Somebody asked about the extension of the date for medals. That will be dealt with in the course of this year —possibly before the end of this session. Abatement is something that requires more than a Ministerial Order. It has been under consideration and is still under consideration but I would be misleading Deputy Collins if I struck any note of optimism.
On a point of clarification, I think I know what Deputy Brennan has in mind. From the point of view of the means test will there be a periodic review of pensions?
Of the allowances annually?

For instance, somebody may have been granted £65 on an inspection by the means test inspector. Will the inspector come back at a later date to review that? Supposing we take a figure of £20 as against the figure to which the Minister says it has been raised, will the man to whom that applies have an opportunity of having it reviewed?
Certainly, but the unfortunate thing is that that review applies both ways. Some may come down on the review.
That is a possibility, but I think that is what the Deputy had in mind.
Vote put and agreed to.
